segment.source: Network security LDAP client signing requirements (Windows 10)
segment.target: Network security LDAP client signing requirements (Windows 10)

segment.source: This security policy reference topic for the IT professional describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for this policy setting.
segment.target: This security policy reference topic for the IT professional describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for this policy setting.

segment.source: Network security: LDAP client signing requirements
segment.target: Network security: LDAP client signing requirements

segment.source: This security policy reference topic for the IT professional describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for this policy setting.
segment.target: This security policy reference topic for the IT professional describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for this policy setting.

segment.source: This information applies to computers running at least the Windows Server 2008 operating system.
segment.target: This information applies to computers running at least the Windows Server 2008 operating system.

segment.source: This policy setting determines the level of data signing that is requested on behalf of client devices that issue LDAP BIND requests.
segment.target: This policy setting determines the level of data signing that is requested on behalf of client devices that issue LDAP BIND requests.

segment.source: The levels of data signing are described in the following list:
segment.target: The levels of data signing are described in the following list:

segment.source: The LDAP BIND request is issued with the caller-specified options.
segment.target: The LDAP BIND request is issued with the caller-specified options.

segment.source: If Transport Layer Security/Secure Sockets Layer (TLS/SSL) has not been started, the LDAP BIND request is initiated with the LDAP data signing option set in addition to the caller-specified options.
segment.target: If Transport Layer Security/Secure Sockets Layer (TLS/SSL) has not been started, the LDAP BIND request is initiated with the LDAP data signing option set in addition to the caller-specified options.

segment.source: If TLS/SSL has been started, the LDAP BIND request is initiated with the caller-specified options.
segment.target: If TLS/SSL has been started, the LDAP BIND request is initiated with the caller-specified options.

segment.source: This level is the same as Negotiate signing.
segment.target: This level is the same as Negotiate signing.

segment.source: However, if the LDAP server's intermediate saslBindInProgress response does not indicate that LDAP traffic signing is required, the caller is returned a message that the LDAP BIND command request failed.
segment.target: However, if the LDAP server's intermediate saslBindInProgress response does not indicate that LDAP traffic signing is required, the caller is returned a message that the LDAP BIND command request failed.

segment.source: Misuse of this policy setting is a common error that can cause data loss or problems with data access or security.
segment.target: Misuse of this policy setting is a common error that can cause data loss or problems with data access or security.

segment.source: Set Domain controller: LDAP server signing requirements to Require signature.
segment.target: Set Domain controller: LDAP server signing requirements to Require signature.

segment.source: If you set the server to require LDAP signatures, you must also set the client devices to do so.
segment.target: If you set the server to require LDAP signatures, you must also set the client devices to do so.

segment.source: Not setting the client devices will prevent client computers from communicating with the server.
segment.target: Not setting the client devices will prevent client computers from communicating with the server.

segment.source: This can cause many features to fail, including user authentication, Group Policy, and logon scripts.
segment.target: This can cause many features to fail, including user authentication, Group Policy, and logon scripts.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: Modifying this setting may affect compatibility with client devices, services, and applications.
segment.target: Modifying this setting may affect compatibility with client devices, services, and applications.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Unsigned network traffic is susceptible to man-in-the-middle attacks in which an intruder captures the packets between the client computer and server, modifies them, and then forwards them to the server.
segment.target: Unsigned network traffic is susceptible to man-in-the-middle attacks in which an intruder captures the packets between the client computer and server, modifies them, and then forwards them to the server.

segment.source: For an LDAP server, this susceptibility means that an attacker could cause a server to make decisions that are based on false or altered data from the LDAP queries.
segment.target: For an LDAP server, this susceptibility means that an attacker could cause a server to make decisions that are based on false or altered data from the LDAP queries.

segment.source: To lower this risk in your network, you can implement strong physical security measures to protect the network infrastructure.
segment.target: To lower this risk in your network, you can implement strong physical security measures to protect the network infrastructure.

segment.source: Also, you can make all types of man-in-the-middle attacks extremely difficult if you require digital signatures on all network packets by means of IPsec authentication headers.
segment.target: Also, you can make all types of man-in-the-middle attacks extremely difficult if you require digital signatures on all network packets by means of IPsec authentication headers.

segment.source: Configure the Network security: LDAP server signing requirements setting to Require signature.
segment.target: Configure the Network security: LDAP server signing requirements setting to Require signature.

segment.source: If you configure the server to require LDAP signatures, you must also configure the client computers.
segment.target: If you configure the server to require LDAP signatures, you must also configure the client computers.

segment.source: If you do not configure the client devices, they cannot communicate with the server, which could cause many features to fail, including user authentication, Group Policy, and logon scripts.
segment.target: If you do not configure the client devices, they cannot communicate with the server, which could cause many features to fail, including user authentication, Group Policy, and logon scripts.
